#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER VIII .
#Text=A QUESTION OF NERVE
#Text=“ That was your victory , Miss
#Text=Stevens .
#Text=Allow me to congratulate you . ”
#Text=If Thurston showed any ill grace in his tone it was without intent .

#Text=But it did seem unfortunate that just as he was waxing eloquent and felt sure of himself and something of a hero , Mona should push him aside as though he were of no account and disperse a bunch of angry cowboys with half a dozen words .
#Text=She looked at him with her direct , blue-gray eyes , and smiled .
#Text=And her smile had no unpleasant uplift at the corners ; it was the dimply , roguish smile of the pastel portrait only several times nicer .
#Text=Re could hardly believe it ; he just opened his eyes wide and stared .

#Text=When he came to a sense of his rudeness , Mona was back in the kitchen helping with the supper dishes , just as though nothing had happened -- unless one observed the deep , apple-red of her cheeks -- while her mother , who showed not the faintest symptoms of collapse , flourished a dish towel made of a bleached flour sack with the stamp showing a faint pink and blue XXXX across the center .
#Text=“ I knew all the time they would n't do anything when it came right to the point , ” she declared .
#Text=“ Bless their hearts , they thought they would -- but they 're too soft-hearted , even when they are mad .
#Text=If yuh go at ' em right yuh can talk ' em over easy .
#Text=It done me good to hear yuh talk right up to ' em , Bud . ” Mrs. Stevens had called hi Bud from the first time she laid eyes on him .
#Text=“ That 's all under the sun they needed -- just somebody to set ' em thinking about the other side .
#Text=You 're a real good speaker ; seems to me you ought to study to be a preacher . ”
#Text=Thurston 's face turned red .

#Text=But presently he forgot everything in his amazement , for Mona the dignified , Mona of the scornful eyes and the chilly smile , actually giggled -- giggled like any ordinary girl , and shot him a glance that had in it pure mirth and roguish teasing , and a dash of coquetry .
#Text=He sat down and giggled with her , feeling idiotically happy and for no reason under the sun that he could name .

#Text=He had promised his conscience that he would go home to the Lazy Eight in the morning , but he did n't ; he somehow contrived , overnight , to invent a brand new excuse for his conscience to swallow or not , as it liked .
#Text=Hank Graves had the same privilege ; as for the Stevens trio , he blessed their hospitable souls for not wanting any excuse whatever for his staying .
#Text=They were frankly glad to have him there ; at least Mrs. Stevens and Jack were .
#Text=As for Mona , he was not so sure , but he hoped she did n't mind .

#Text=This was the reason inspired by his great desire : he was going to write a story , and Mona was unconsciously to furnish the material for his heroine , and so , of course , he needed to be there so that he might study his subject .
#Text=That sounded very well , to himself , but to Hank Graves , for some reason , it seemed very funny .
#Text=When Thurston told him , Hank was taken with a fit of strangling that turned his face a dark purple .
#Text=Afterward he explained brokenly that something had got down his Sunday throat -- and Thurston , who had never heard of a man 's Sunday throat , eyed him with suspicion .

#Text=Hank blinked at him with tears still in his quizzical eyes and slapped him on the back , after the way of the West -- and any other enlightened country where men are not too dignified to be their real selves -- and drawled , in a way peculiar to himself :
#Text=“ That 's all right , Bud .
#Text=You stay right here as long as yuh want to .
#Text=I do n't blame yuh -- if I was you I 'd want to spend a lot uh time studying this particular brand uh female girl myself .
#Text=She 's out uh sight , Bud -- and I do n't believe any uh the boys has got his loop on her so far ; though I could name a dozen or so that would be tickled to death if they had .
#Text=You just go right ahead and file your little , old claim -- ”
#Text=“ You 're getting things mixed , ” Thurston interrupted , rather testily .
#Text=“ I 'm not in love with her .
#Text=I , well , it 's like this : if you were going to paint a picture of those mountains off there , you 'd want to be where you could look at them -- would n't you ?
#Text=You would n't necessarily want to -- to own them , just because you felt they 'd make a fine picture .
#Text=Your interest would be , er , entirely impersonal . ”
#Text=“ Uh-huh , ” Hank agreed , his keen eyes searching Phil 's face amusedly .
#Text=“ Therefore , it does n't follow that I 'm getting foolish about a girl just because I -- hang it !
#Text=what the Dickens makes you look at a fellow that way ?
#Text=You make me ? ”
#Text=“ Uh-huh , ” said Hank again , smoothing the lower half of his face with one hand .
#Text=“ You 're a mighty nice little boy , Bud .
#Text=I 'll bet Mona thinks so , too and when yuh get growed up you 'll know a whole lot more than yuh do right now .
#Text=Well , I guess I 'll be moving .
#Text=When yuh get that -- er -- story done , you 'll come back to the ranch , I reckon .
#Text=Be good . ”

#Text=Thurston watched him ride away , and then flounced , oh , men do flounce at times , in spirit , if not in deed ; and there would be no lack of the deed if only they wore skirts that could rustle indignantly in sympathy with the wearer -- to his room .
#Text=Plainly , Hank did not swallow the excuse any more readily than did his conscience .
